awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Designing Soluble Inorganic Nanomaterials for Flowable Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
The widespread adoption of renewable energy technologies like solar and wind power depends critically on the ability to store massive quantities of electricity in rechargeable batteries. The purpose of this project is to design a new generation of high performing materials for liquid-phase energy storage systems like redox flow batteries, which are especially suitable for storing electricity on a large scale. Experiments will be undertaken to learn how the molecular properties of soluble, earth-abundant nanomaterials influence their practical performance in liquid-phase battery systems. The continued progress toward a sustainable energy system will only be possible through training of a globally competitive STEM workforce prepared to innovate and deploy new technologies. In pursuit of this goal, the project integrates several activities centered on the training of competitive undergraduate and graduate students. Alongside the research activities, this program includes a new educational effort directed at training undergraduate students to synthesize, test, and critically evaluate liquid-phase battery materials. The project includes the creation of resources for teaching laboratories—encompassing new curricular materials and designs for low-cost experimental hardware—aimed at teaching the core concepts of electrochemical energy storage to students at three different institutions across the mid-Atlantic region.

The overarching objective of this collaborative project is to build a framework for the design of soluble inorganic nanomaterials for liquid-phase, flowable electrochemical energy storage (EES). This objective will be addressed through hypothesis-driven studies targeting two families of nanoscale metal oxide assemblies: polyoxometalate clusters and solubilized metal oxide nanoparticles. These charge carriers each feature a high degree of tunability via compositional modifications of their metal oxide cores and solubilizing ligands. This project will probe the overarching hypothesis that control over these molecular characteristics will enable the design of soluble inorganic nanomaterials that exhibit fast electron-transfer kinetics, high solubility, and long-term stability over a wide range of electrochemical potentials. A series of studies focused on targeted synthetic modifications of vanadium- and titanium-oxide nanomaterials is planned; these materials will be characterized in detail using a unique, multimodal analytical approach that affords simultaneous measurements of their fundamental redox chemistry and device-level figures of merit. The research will contribute to the advancement of EES by enabling the rational design of soluble, redox-active inorganic nanomaterials. Successful completion of this work will ultimately result in the validation of a new class of inorganic charge carriers based on transition metal oxide architectures for flow batteries and related EES technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
This award has supported collaborative research between PI McKone, and co-PIs Cook and Matson focused on the development of redox active metal-oxide assemblies as charge carriers. The intellectual merit of this proposal focuses on advancing the science and practice of grid-scale electrochemical energy storage through the development of soluble metal oxide clusters and nanoparticles. The overarching hypothesis is that soluble nanomaterials based on metal oxide structural motifs will exhibit fast electron transfer kinetics, high solubilities, and stabilities that span a wide range of electrochemical potentials, rendering these materials ideal for redox flow battery technologies. Key work from the Cook Lab involved the design of materials that could be suspended in solvent and access multiple charge states. We initially explored materials based on titanium dioxide and were successful in making stable suspensions. The highly reducing conditions required to store charge on the titanium dioxide nanoparticles resulted in unwanted redox chemistry of the surface ligands and so our efforts turned to iron-based coordination polymers.

Prussian Blue and its analogue containing copper are redox active and capable of storing charge. However, these materials have not been used in flowable designs. Over the course of our work, we discovered how to tune the redox properties of a copper-containing Prussian Blue analogue such that it remained redox active as a suspension by changing the molecules decorating the surface of the material. Although this suspension was not stable in the long-term, we established that the dispersions could be maintained by further tuning the surface ligands.

Our electrochemical studies of solid and suspended Prussian Blue materials inspired studies of so-called “redox targeted” batteries. These are devices that contain a solid-phase energy storage material that is charged or discharged with the help of soluble molecules that can shuttle electrons or holes. Typical devices use multiple species, but in our work, we have designed single-component batteries where the solubility of the charge carrier is tuned to allow it to act as a bulk storage medium in addition to shuttling charge through the solution. Our fundamental studies have the potential to simplify these hybrid flow designs.

Due to the societal consequences of energy storage research, a key broader impact of this project was the training of undergraduate and graduate students. The ever-increasing demand for energy can only be met by the mentoring of a globally competitive STEM workforce prepared to innovate and adapt new technologies. This training is taking place through direct participation in research at the postdoctoral researcher and graduate student level. To target more broadly the education and training of undergraduate students, our collaboration developed an advanced laboratory experiment related to the themes of solution-based energy storage investigated by our collaboration.


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Timothy Cook
